title: Docs-as-Code & Engineering Tenets for Standards and Maintainability
context: As the codebase and team grow, maintaining high engineering standards, documentation quality, and long-term maintainability becomes increasingly challenging. Inconsistent documentation, lack of enforced standards, and scattered UX messaging can lead to confusion, onboarding friction, and technical debt. A unified docs-as-code approach, enforced by CI and pre-commit, is needed to ensure quality and consistency across all tools (DAT, PPTX Generator, SOV Analyzer).
decision_primary: All engineering standards and documentation are managed as code. MkDocs and mkdocstrings are used for documentation generation. Pre-commit hooks and CI enforce linting, formatting, and Google-style docstrings. The UX message catalog is the single source of truth for user-facing messaging.

decision_details.approach: Adopt docs-as-code using MkDocs and mkdocstrings for all documentation. Enforce Google-style docstrings in code. Use pre-commit and CI to check lint/format for both code and docs. UX message catalog is maintained as a versioned, centralized artifact.
constraints: All documentation must be version-controlled and built with MkDocs.
All public functions/classes require Google-style docstrings.
Pre-commit and CI must block merges on lint/format/doc violations.
UX messaging must be sourced from the central catalog.

consequences: Documentation and standards are always up-to-date and enforced.
Onboarding is easier and technical debt is reduced.
Slight increase in up-front effort for contributors.
All user-facing messaging is consistent and traceable.

alternatives_considered.name: Ad-hoc Documentation and Manual Standards
alternatives_considered.cons: Inconsistent quality, high maintenance burden, poor onboarding.

alternatives_considered.name: Docs Separate from Codebase
alternatives_considered.cons: Docs quickly become outdated, hard to enforce standards.
alternatives_considered.rejected_reason: Not sustainable for a growing team.

tradeoffs: Requires discipline and up-front investment in tooling, but ensures long-term maintainability and quality. Some learning curve for contributors.
rollout_plan: Set up MkDocs and mkdocstrings for all documentation.
Implement pre-commit and CI checks for lint/format/docstring compliance.
Centralize UX message catalog and enforce usage.
rollback_plan: Revert to previous documentation and standards approach (not recommended).
metrics_to_watch: CI/pre-commit failure rates for docs/code standards.
Incidents of outdated or inconsistent documentation.

guardrails.rule: All documentation and standards must be managed as code and enforced by CI.

cross_cutting_guardrails: Documentation Quality: All public APIs and modules must be documented (see ADR-0045#tier-boundaries)
references: ADR-0015_3-Tier-Document-Model: Defines the doc hierarchy this ADR enables
docs/: MkDocs documentation for all tools (DAT, PPTX, SOV)
